column5: normally, the temperature should be reported at the 2 meter height

column4: "skin" temperature (i.e., SST for open ocean)
monthly mean of the daily-minimum near-surface air temperature.
column5: normally, this should be reported at the 2 meter height.
column10: time: minimum within days time: mean over days

column4: monthly mean of the daily-maximum near-surface air temperature.
column5: normally, this should be reported at the 2 meter height.
column10: time: maximum within days time: mean over days

column4: not, in general, the same as surface pressure
not, in general, the same as mean sea-level pressure

column5: normally, the the wind component should be reported at the 10 meter height
normally, the the wind component should be reported at the 10 meter height

column4: This is the mean of the speed, not the speed computed from the mean u and v components of wind
column5: normally, the the wind  should be reported at the 10 meter height

column4: This is the relative humidity with respect to liquid water for T> 0 C, and with respect to ice for T<0 C.
column5: express as a percentage.  Normally, the relative humidity  should be reported at the 2 meter height
Normally, the specific humidity should be reported at the 2 meter height

column4: at surface; includes both liquid and solid phases from all types of clouds (both large-scale and convective)
at surface; includes precipitation of all forms of water in the solid phase
at surface; includes both liquid and solid phases.
at surface; flux of water into the atmosphere due to conversion of both liquid and solid phases to vapor (from underlying surface and vegetation)

column2: Surface Snow and Ice Sublimation Flux
column4: The snow and ice sublimation flux is the loss of snow and ice mass from the surface resulting from their conversion to water vapor that enters the atmosphere.
column5: This differs from sbl appearing in table Limon in that the flux is averaged over the entire grid cell, not just the land portion.

column4: includes both evaporation and sublimation
at the top of the atmosphere
at the top of the atmosphere
at the top of the atmosphere (to be compared with satellite measurements)
vertically integrated through the atmospheric column
for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Include both large-scale and convective cloud.

mass of condensed (liquid + ice) water in the column divided by the area of the column (not just the area of the cloudy portion of the column). Includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeor affects the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

mass of ice water in the column divided by the area of the column (not just the area of the cloudy portion of the column). Includes precipitating frozen hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeor affects the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

column2: Net Downward Flux at Top of Model
column4: i.e., at the top of that portion of the atmosphere where dynamics are explicitly treated by the model. This is reported only if it differs from the net downward radiative flux at the top of the atmosphere.

column2: Air Pressure at Convective Cloud Base
Air Pressure at Convective Cloud Top

column4: Fraction of time that convection occurs in the grid cell .

column2: Fraction of Time Shallow Convection Occurs
column4: Fraction of time that shallow convection occurs in the grid cell.
column5: For models with a distinct shallow convection scheme only.

column2: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to All Anthropogenic Emissions of CO2
column4: This is requested only for the emission-driven coupled carbon climate model runs.  Does not include natural fire sources but, includes all anthropogenic sources, including fossil fuel use, cement production, agricultural burning, and sources associated with anthropogenic land use change excluding forest regrowth.

column2: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to Fossil Fuel Emissions of CO2
column4: This is the prescribed anthropogenic CO2 flux from fossil fuel use, including cement production, and flaring (but not from land-use changes, agricultural burning, forest regrowth, etc.)
column5: This is requested only for the emission-driven coupled carbon climate model runs.

column2: Surface Carbon Mass Flux into the Atmosphere Due to Natural Sources
column4: This is what the atmosphere sees (on its own grid).  This field should be equivalent to the combined natural fluxes of carbon (requested in the L_mon and O_mon tables) that account for natural exchanges between the atmosphere and land or ocean reservoirs (i.e., "net ecosystem biospheric productivity", for land, and "air to sea CO2 flux", for ocean.)
column5: Report from all simulations (both emission-driven and concentration-driven) performed by models with fully interactive and responsive carbon cycles.
